if statement

　The if statement is a syntax that determines whether or not to execute a part of the script based on a conditional decision, such as "if XX do YY".
　The syntax is as follows:

if(expression)
    Statement or block
else
    Statement or block
　The first "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluating expression is true, and the second "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluation is false. After else, you do not need to write it if you do not need it.

例:
    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");

    if(a<b)
    {
        var t;
        t=a; a=b; b=t; // swaps a and b 
    }

    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are the same");
    else
        inform("a and b are different");

Correspondence between if and else

　else has the rule "corresponds to the previous, if which does not yet correspond to an else".

For example,

    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
        else // ●
            statement;
    else // ★
        statement;
　The else of ★ corresponds to the if of ★, and the else of ● corresponds to the if of ●.
　Freestyle languages such as TJS2 even incorrectly indent
    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    else // ●
        statement;
　Even if you write, you need to be careful because the correspondence is as above.
　If you want a clear break,

    if(expr) { // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    }
    else // ★
        statement;
　please take the method of enclosing in a block like the above.
